instruction: Write a continuation for this paragraph: This is the second album recorded and published by the band in Italy, after their exile in that country as a result of the Coup d'état in Chile in 1973...
output:
...During their time in Italy, the band faced multiple challenges and adversities, but also found a new audience and a connection with the community of political exiles. Their music became a powerful tool of protest and resistance, carrying messages of hope and denunciation through the lyrics of their songs.

On this album, the band explored a unique mix of sounds, fusing their Latin American roots with European influences and other musical currents of the time. The creativity and passion that permeated each note and word expressed the deep feeling of loss, but also the determination to move forward in the fight for justice and freedom.

The success of this second album opened new doors for the band in Europe and allowed them to bring their message to international audiences. As their popularity grew, so did their commitment to the political and social cause that united them. Their music became a symbol of resistance and solidarity for many, not only for those who had been affected by the tragedy in Chile, but also for those fighting for justice in different parts of the world.

In every chord and every verse, the band channeled the passion and emotion that arose from their experience in exile, creating a musical legacy that would live on in history. Through their art, the band transcended borders and language barriers, touching the hearts of people from different cultures and backgrounds.

This second album, more than just a musical production, was a powerful testament to human resilience and the tireless search for freedom and dignity. Its legacy lives on as a reminder of the importance of music as a vehicle for social change and as a tribute to all those who fought and continue to fight for a more just and humane world.

instruction: In what way did Augustus pretend not to respect Virgil? Considering the previous question, write a context that contains the answer. It can be from 1 to 20 sentences. The context:
output: According to tradition, Virgil traveled to Greece around 19 BC to revise the Aeneid. After meeting Augustus in Athens and deciding to return home, Virgil contracted a fever while visiting a city near Megara. After crossing to Italy by ship, weakened by illness, Virgil died in the port of Brundisium on September 21, 19 BC. Augustus ordered Virgil's literary executors, Lucius Varius Rufus and Plotius Tucca, to ignore Virgil's own wish that the poem be burned, instead ordering it to be published with as few editorial changes as possible. As a result, the extant text of the Aeneid may contain errors that Virgil planned to correct before publication. However, the only obvious imperfections are a few lines of verse that are not finished metrically (i.e., not a complete line of dactile hexameter). Some scholars have argued that Virgil deliberately left these metrical lines incomplete for dramatic effect. Other alleged imperfections are subject to academic debate.

instruction: Which states in the US are not connected to other states in the US?
output:
In the United States, there are two states that are not connected to other states by land:

1) Alaska: It is a state located in the extreme northwest of North America. It is not connected by land to the other US states as it is separated by Canada.

2) Hawaii: It is an archipelago in the central Pacific Ocean and is located approximately 3,200 kilometers southwest of California. Due to its geographical location in the middle of the Pacific, it is not connected by land to any other state.

Both states are non-contiguous territories, meaning they are geographically isolated from the rest of the continental United States. However, they are an integral part of the country and enjoy all the rights and benefits of American citizenship.

instruction: What language is spoken in French Guiana?
output: The linguistic landscape in French Guiana is very diverse and complex. This area is multilingual; The official language is French, but the most spoken is the Franco-Guyanese Creole based on French lexology, as well as others such as English brought by the Guyanese and Americans. The Franco-Guyanese Amazon is home to several native languages ​​of the area. Portuguese is also present in its Amazon, brought by the Brazilians. Spanish is present to a lesser extent throughout French Guiana. This language has been brought mainly by Peruvians, Colombians and Dominicans who arrived in Cayenne. Dutch has been present since colonial times on the border with Suriname. Haitian Creole is present in the region brought by Haitians.

instruction: What is the gradient descent algorithm?
output:
If we have a multivariable function f: R^k -> R (that is, it takes k variables and returns a real), the gradient of said function is a vector of k components, where each component tells the derivative of f with respect to said variable. This vector tells the direction of greatest rise with respect to the given position.
The gradient descent algorithm consists of descending in the opposite direction of the gradient. Eventually a local minimum point is reached. If the function f is convex then the global minimum point is reached.
This algorithm is very important in the field of Machine Learning, since it is used to train supervised models.

instruction:
Summarize what you have read Described as the "sociologist of anti-globalization", Boaventura de Sousa Santos is one of the main promoters of the World Social Forum.

This is how he presents it to us in his new essay, "The cruel pedagogy of the virus", in which he says that the covid-19 pandemic is the way in which our planet is telling us enough is enough. Will we learn? That's the big question now.

Boaventura de Sousa Santos is director emeritus of the Social Studies center at the University of Coimbra, in Portugal; distinguished researcher at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Law School, in the United States.

Described as the "sociologist of anti-globalization", he is one of the main promoters of the World Social Forum.

In his new work, the sociologist reflects on all the lessons that this virus is leaving us, which has highlighted the inequalities of our society, of our development model, of which Santos is very critical. 

End of Maybe you're also interested

A virus capable of infecting anyone, yes, but it has targeted the most vulnerable, the poor.

"30% of the world's population lacks water," he says. "How are they going to wash their hands? They need the little water they have to eat and drink."

What follows is a summary of BBC Mundo's telephone conversation with Boaventura de Sousa Santos.

Warlike rhetoric has been used from various spheres and this virus has been described as an enemy. You refer to him as a cruel pedagogue. What is the pedagogy of this virus?

This virus is a pedagogue in the sense that it is giving us several lessons. The problem is knowing if we are going to listen to them and learn them. 

It is cruel because the only way the virus has to teach us is by killing, killing innocent people, and it does so by the thousands and thousands.

What is he trying to teach us?

The virus is a pedagogue that is teaching us that Mother Earth is not satisfied with the development model we have. We are a very small, tiny part of...\nSummary in the same language as the doc:
output: Considered one of the great references among left-wing thinkers, the Portuguese sociologist Boaventura de Sousa Santos believes that the new coronavirus is a great pedagogue.

instruction: Write code in Python to generate the first 10 numbers of the Fibonacci sequence.
output:
def fibonacci(n):
    """Generate the first n numbers of the Fibonacci sequence"""
    num1, num2 = 0, 1
    count = 0
    
    sequence = []

    while count < n:
        sequence.append(num1)
        num1, num2 = num2, num1 + num2
        count += 1
        
    return sequence

# Function call
n = 10
result = fibonacci(n)
print(result)

instruction: About Lollapalooza: where does it take place, who started it and what is it?
output: Lollapalooza is an annual music festival held in Grant Park in Chicago, Illinois. It began in 1991 as a farewell tour for Perry Farrell, singer of the group Jane's Addiction. The festival includes a variety of musical genres including alternative rock, heavy metal, punk rock, hip hop, and electronic dance music. The festivals welcome around 400,000 people each year. Some notable headliners include: the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Chance the Rapper, Metallica, and Lady Gage. Lollapalooza is one of the largest and most iconic festivals in the world and a major cultural event in Chicago. Currently it is also celebrated in other parts of the world, with Chile being the first country outside the United States to host the festival in 2011.

instruction:
What important event is this text about?

The Eredvi Basilica of St. George is a Georgian Orthodox church from the early 10th century in the village of Eredvi, in the Shida Kartli region, currently the disputed territory of South Ossetia. It was built by the architect Tevdore Taplaisdze, who laid the foundations of the church in 906 according to a Georgian inscription on the building. The church is a three-nave basilica that, despite subsequent reconstructions, has largely preserved its original architectural features. The church is included in the list of Immovable Cultural Monuments of National Significance of Georgia. After the 2008 Russo-Georgian war, Georgians lost access to the church and services there were restricted by South Ossetian authorities.
output:
The text is about the "Basilica of St. George of Eredvi", a Georgian Orthodox church from the early 10th century located in a disputed area of ​​South Ossetia.

The important event mentioned is the "Russian-Georgian War of 2008", during which Georgians lost access to the church due to restrictions imposed by the South Ossetian authorities. This war took place in August 2008 and was an armed conflict between Georgia on the one hand, and Russia and the independence movements of South Ossetia and Abkhazia on the other.

instruction: Read the following title and write an article according to the headline: Why do hundreds of people flee the United States to go to Canada?
output:
At Roxham Road, a popular border crossing near Saint-Bernard-de-Lacolle, Quebec, there is a line of people laden with suitcases seeking asylum. And there are more and more. 

In fact, the army is building a camp to accommodate 500 people arriving from the American town of Plattsburgh, in the state of New York.

More than 3,300 people have arrived in Quebec between January and June of this year, according to Canadian officials.

And in Montreal, the Olympic stadium already functions as a shelter for immigrants crossing the border. 

Trump vs. Trudeau

Francine Dupuis, from the provincial Praida refugee integration programme, told the BBC that another 1,200 people entered through this crossing in July, 90% of whom come from Haiti. 

In May, US President Donald Trump announced the end of the program that extended temporary protection to Haitian citizens in the United States after the 2010 earthquake. 

This protection will end in January 2018 and Quebec, a city whose official language is also French, is positioned as a tempting option. 

These immigrants, who risk freezing to death crossing from the US to Canada, fear being deported under Trump's policies and returned to dangerous or poverty-stricken places.

In Canada, they estimate, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's immigration policy will be more benevolent than Trump's. At least they saw it on their social networks. 

However, Marjorie Villefranche, director of the organization La Maison d'Haiti in Montreal, explained to the BBC: "Proving that you are really an asylum seeker is a very long and exhausting process."

instruction: Write a story for a five-year-old child, taking the idea of ​​the Little Prince, in a new and original version in 500 words.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a little explorer named Nico, who lived on a tiny planet far away called Tinyland. In Tinyland, everything was so small that the flowers looked like bright little stars and the mountains looked like soft green hills.

One day, while Nico was playing among the flowers, he saw something shining among the petals. It was a little golden star! He took it in his hands and looked at it in wonder. The little star began to shine even brighter and suddenly spoke: "Hello, Nico, I am Estela, a traveling star. I have come to Tinyland to discover your wonders."

Nico was very excited and decided to show Estela every corner of his little world. Together they explored the magical little forest, where the trees whispered stories and the birds sang enchanted melodies. Afterwards, they climbed the Emerald Mountain, where they found little laughing elves who gave them laughter and joy.

On their journey, they also met Nube, a smiling cloud that floated through the blue sky and took them on a flight through the fluffy clouds. From there, Nico and Estela watched the stars in the sky, and Estela told them stories about other planets and distant galaxies.

One day, while they were walking near the crystal-clear river, they found a strange little creature. It was round and had small wings. "Hello, I'm Alita! I'm the last dragonfly in Pequeñolandia," she said sadly. "No one has noticed that I'm the last one, everyone is too busy to notice my existence."

Nico and Estela felt sad for Alita and decided to help her. Together they built a small shelter for the dragonflies, and little by little, more dragonflies began to arrive in Pequeñolandia. Alita no longer felt alone, and the dragonflies became the guardians of the magical little forest.

Over time, Nico and Estela became great friends. Every day, they traveled around Littleland exploring and discovering new wonders. One day, while they were on top of Emerald Mountain, Nico asked Estela if she wanted to stay in Littleland with him. "I'd love to, Nico, but I'm a traveling star and I must continue my path through the universe," Estela replied with a smile.

Nico felt a little sad, but he knew that he would always have the memories of his adventure with Estela in his heart. And so, with a warm hug and a sparkle in her eyes, Estela said goodbye to Nico and continued her journey.

From that day on, Nico never stopped exploring Littleland. He always remembered Estela and looked up at the sky, knowing that, somewhere, his star friend was still shining. And although Nico never saw her again, the magic of their friendship made Littleland an even more special place full of wonders.

And so, this little explorer learned that friendship has no borders and that, although the stars may be far away, they will always shine in the hearts of those who love them.

The End.

instruction: How is it to emigrate from Latin America to Europe?
output:
Emigrating from Latin America to Europe can be a challenging but satisfying process.
The change in culture, food, traditions, missing family must be considered.
Plus, the paperwork involved and the stress involved can sometimes get anyone off track.
On the other hand, in general, in Europe you can aspire to a much better quality of life, with greater opportunities, fewer security risks, and more financial stability once you settle down and find a good job. The European Union has several laws that protect citizens, and one can have higher quality in public services.

instruction:
Content: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered on October 2, 2018.

I walked down a tree-lined street in a quiet area of ​​Istanbul, Turkey, and approached a cream-colored mansion adorned with video surveillance cameras.

A year ago, an exiled Saudi journalist made the same journey: Jamal Khashoggi was recorded by closed circuit cameras (CCTV). They would be the last images that were captured of him.

He entered the Saudi consulate in the Turkish city and was killed by a death squad.

Jamal Khashoggi entered the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October 2, 2018 and did not leave again.

But the consulate was bugged with microphones from the Turkish intelligence service, so everything was recorded: the planning to kill him and the execution.

Only a few people have heard those tapes. Two of them spoke exclusively to the BBC's Panorama programme.

British Baroness Helena Kennedy, lawyer and human rights expert, listened to Jamal Khashoggi's agony.

"The horror of hearing someone's voice, of hearing the fear in their voice, and [knowing] that you're hearing something [that happened] live makes you feel chills all over your body."

Baroness Helena Kennedy listened to the recordings that recorded the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

Kennedy took detailed notes of the conversations she overheard between members of the Saudi death squad.

"You can hear them laughing. It's a chilling business. They're there waiting, knowing that this man is going to come and be killed and dismembered."

Kennedy was invited to join a team led by Agnès Callamard, the United Nations special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions.

Callamard told me about her determination to use her own mandate to investigate Khashoggi's murder when the UN was reluctant to launch an international criminal investigation.

Agnès Callamard is a human rights expert and is the current special rapporteur.
output: WARNING: the content of this note may offend your sensitivity.

instruction: What are the most important cities in Cuba?
output:
Some of the most important cities in Cuba are:

Havana: The capital of Cuba and the largest city in the country. Havana is known for its colonial architecture, vibrant streets, rich culture and lively nightlife.

Santiago de Cuba: The second largest city in Cuba, located on the east coast of the island. It is known for its influence on Afro-Cuban music and culture, as well as its revolutionary history.

Camagüey: Located in the center of Cuba, Camagüey is famous for its labyrinth of narrow streets and its colonial architecture. It is one of the oldest cities in Cuba.

Holguín: Located on the northeast coast of Cuba, Holguín is known for its natural beauty and beaches, such as Guardalavaca, and for being the "City of Parks" due to its abundance of green areas.

Cienfuegos: Known as the "Pearl of the South," Cienfuegos is famous for its neoclassical architecture and port. It has been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.

Santa Clara: This city is famous for being the site of the Battle of Santa Clara during the Cuban Revolution and for the mausoleum of Che Guevara, which attracts visitors interested in Cuba's revolutionary history.

Trinidad: A well-preserved colonial city that has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is famous for its cobblestone streets and ancient architecture.

Varadero: Although not a city in the traditional sense, Varadero is a popular tourist destination in Cuba, known for its beautiful white sand beaches and its range of resorts and hotels.

These are some of the most important and well-known cities in Cuba, but the country has many other interesting cities and towns that offer a unique insight into the culture, history, and natural beauty of the island.

instruction: What is Albert Einstein's theory of relativity?
output: Albert Einstein's theory of relativity is a fundamental theory in physics that is divided into two parts: special relativity and general relativity. Special relativity, published in 1905, states that the laws of physics are the same for all observers, regardless of their relative speed. In addition, it introduces the famous equation E=mc², which relates the energy (E) and the mass (m) of an object. On the other hand, general relativity, introduced in 1915, describes gravity as the curvature of space-time caused by mass and energy, which revolutionized our understanding of gravity.

instruction: Briefly explain what the fast Fourier transform consists of and some of its applications, without going into the mathematical details.
output:
The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an algorithm that allows the discrete Fourier transform to be computed efficiently. The idea is that the Fourier matrix of size N (consisting of the unit roots of N) can be decomposed into the product of the Fourier matrix of size N/2 and several sparse matrices. From this, a divide and conquer algorithm can be used to compute said transform, in O(n * log n) time, much more efficient than the naive way, which has O(n^2) time complexity.

This algorithm has many applications in signal processing, denoising, convolutions, correlations, etc. In the context of competitive programming it is mainly used to multiply two polynomials of degree N in O(n*log n) time.

instruction: Write a continuation for this paragraph: In 2006, FIBA ​​made the decision to expand the championship again to 24 teams and introduce the format currently in use. Under this format, teams are divided into four first-round groups of six teams each. If the teams tie at the end of the preliminary round, the tie is broken according to the following criteria:
output:
1) Point difference: The team with the largest point difference between points scored and points received will be placed higher in the table.
2) Points scored: If the tie persists, the total points scored by each team in the group stage will be considered.
3) Match result between tied teams: If two teams have the same score and faced each other, the team that won the head-to-head will have the advantage.
4) Difference in goals in the games between tied teams: If the tie persists between two teams that faced each other, the difference in points in the game between them will be compared.
5) Points scored in matches between tied teams: If necessary, the total points scored in direct matches between tied teams will be considered.
6) Point difference of all matches: If there is still a tie, the point difference in all group stage matches will be observed.
7) Points scored in all matches: If the tie continues, the total points scored in all matches in the group stage will be counted.
These tie-breaking criteria guarantee a fair and orderly classification in the event of equal points between the teams participating in the tournament.

instruction: What is test-time augmentation?
output: Data augmentation in testing is a technique that helps neural networks improve their performance. The idea is when you are in inference time, these variations are made to the test samples to have more predictions of each one. instruction: What important event is this text about?: The Basilica of St. George of Eredvi is a Georgian Orthodox church from the early 10th century in the village of Eredvi, in the Shida Kartli region, currently the disputed territory of South Ossetia. The church is a three-nave basilica that, despite subsequent reconstructions, has largely preserved its original architectural features. The church is included in the list of Immovable Cultural Monuments of National Significance of Georgia. After the 2008 Russo-Georgian war, Georgians lost access to the church and services there were restricted by South Ossetian authorities.

instruction: Refer to the following passage and then answer the question later in the same language as the passage: Joe Elliott proposed the name "Deaf Leopard" which was originally a band name he came up with while writing reviews for imaginary rock bands in his class of English. He was replaced by Frank Noon. By the end of the month, Rick Allen, then only 15 years old, had joined the band as their full-time drummer. Sales of the EP skyrocketed after the song "Getcha Rocks Off" received extensive airtime by renowned BBC Radio 1 DJ John Peel, regarded at the time as a champion of punk rock and new wave music. Throughout 1979, the band developed a loyal following among British hard rock and heavy metal fans and were considered among the leaders of the new wave of the British heavy metal movement. Their growing popularity led to a record deal with the Phonogram/Vertigo record label (Mercury Records) in the US. Def Leppard's original management, MSB, a local duo consisting of Pete Martin and Frank Stuart-Brown, were fired after that Martin and Joe Elliott got into a fight over a road incident. The band approached Peter Mensch of Leber-Krebs' management, who had booked them on a UK tour supporting AC/DC. Mensch, who admitted that he had his eye on the band, became his manager.  Question: Who was a member of Def Leppard?
output: Throughout their history, Def Leppard has had several members. Their initial members were Joe Elliot, Tony Kenning, and Steve Clark. Kenning left the band and was replaced by Frank Noon. Rick Allen joined the band as a full-time drummer.

instruction:
Luis Almagro after Evo Morales' resignation in Bolivia: "The call for elections is necessary"\tThat's what the Uruguayan diplomat told BBC Mundo this Sunday after President Evo Morales resigned from the presidency of Bolivia.

And the issue is not minor, as Morales resigned hours after the OAS reported that its audit had detected various irregularities in the counting of votes in the elections of October 20.

The OAS made its report "recommend another electoral process" and a second round, something that Morales himself regretted when announcing his resignation.

And the core of the dispute was whether or not the president had achieved the 10 percentage point difference necessary to avoid a second round.

End of Perhaps you are also interested

After the OAS report, Morales announced the call for new elections, as requested by the audit, but that did not satisfy the opposition, who continued to insist on his resignation.

The idea of ​​new elections with Morales in government did not seem good to the military either, who also on Sunday "suggested" that the president step aside.

That, together with the police "mutiny", with numerous units declared in rebellion, had left the president in a very delicate situation.

Morales announced his resignation in a televised statement together with his vice president.

The events have provoked several reactions internationally, especially that of Mexico, which offered asylum in its embassy in La Paz to Morales and other officials of its executive and legislative branches.

The Mexican Secretary of Foreign Relations, Marcelo Ebrard, said that his country "maintains the recognition of the democratically elected government" of Morales and that it will not recognize a government that does not emanate from a legitimate constitutional process.

For Mexico it is "a setback for democracy in Latin America" ​​and Ebrard said that they would call an urgent meeting with the OAS to ask for explanations about its silence in the face of the events in Bolivia.

The controversial recount

The deep political crisis that led Morales to resign had its...
output: The Secretary General of the OAS, Luis Almagro, considers that in Bolivia "the call for elections is necessary."

instruction: Write a continuation for this paragraph: She became first lady of Equatorial Guinea in 1979, after the rise to power of her husband Teodoro Obiang Nguema through a coup d'état...
output:
...Assuming this new role, María dedicated herself tirelessly to promoting various initiatives in favor of the most vulnerable sectors of society. With a clear vision of contributing to the development of the country, she founded the Foundation for Social Development and Integration (FUNDASI), a non-profit organization aimed at improving the quality of life of the most disadvantaged Guineans.

FUNDASI ​​focused on key areas such as education, health and women's empowerment. Maria worked closely with different government actors and international organizations to ensure that the projects had a lasting and significant impact. In the educational field, scholarship programs and improvements in school infrastructure were implemented to ensure that more children and young people had access to quality education.

In the health sector, María led mass vaccination campaigns and promoted the construction of hospitals and health centers in remote regions. Additionally, she dedicated herself to raising awareness about the importance of prevention and health care, especially on issues such as malaria and HIV/AIDS.

One of the causes that María was most passionate about was the empowerment of women. Through training and microcredit programs, FUNDASI ​​supported women entrepreneurs so they could start and expand their own businesses. Maria firmly believed that when women are economically empowered, the entire community benefits.

Over the years, Maria's work as first lady was recognized internationally, and she was invited to participate in forums and conferences on sustainable development and human rights. Her commitment and dedication earned her awards and recognition, but what made her most proud was the positive impact that her projects generated in the lives of the citizens of Equatorial Guinea.

In her role as first lady, María also promoted the country's culture and traditions, highlighting the artistic wealth and cultural diversity of Equatorial Guinea in the international arena.

Her legacy as first lady transcended the barriers of time and her work continued to be a source of inspiration for future generations. After leaving office, María decided to continue working on social and humanitarian development projects, establishing her own foundation to continue contributing to the well-being of her country and other places that needed support.

María and Teodoro Obiang Nguema became a formidable team, working together for the progress of Equatorial Guinea and the well-being of its people. Her dedication and leadership left an indelible mark on the country's history and an example to follow for the rest of the African continent.

instruction:
A prime (or prime) number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number. For example, 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only positive integer factors, while 6 is composite because it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6. The fundamental theorem of arithmetic states the central role of primes in number theory: any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to the order. The uniqueness of this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because arbitrarily many instances of 1 can be included in any factorization, e.g., 3, 1 · 3, 1 · 1 · 3, etc. They are all valid factorizations of 3.

With reference to the previous context, what are numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 3 or more numbers called?
output: Numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 3 or more numbers are called composite numbers.

instruction: How is DNA contracted from RNA? Considering the previous question, write a context that contains the answer. It can be from 1 to 20 sentences.
output: DNA is spliced ​​in the process of transcription, during which an RNA molecule is synthesized from a specific DNA sequence. This process is essential for gene expression and protein synthesis in a cell. During transcription, the enzyme RNA polymerase binds to the DNA sequence and uses one of the strands as a template to synthesize a complementary RNA strand. As RNA polymerase moves along the DNA, the newly synthesized RNA strand is formed through base pairing: adenine (A) with uracil (U) in RNA, cytosine (C) with guanine (G). After transcription is complete, the RNA is separated from the DNA and directed to perform its specific function in the cell, either as messenger RNA (mRNA) for protein synthesis or in other regulatory roles.

instruction: Give me an example of trivia in this category: Geography.
output:
How many time zones does the United States have? 
The United States has a total of six major time zones. These are:

1) Eastern Time Zone (Eastern Standard Time - EST) / (Eastern Daylight Time - EDT during daylight saving time).
2) Central Time Zone (Central Standard Time - CST) / (Central Daylight Time - CDT during daylight saving time).
3) Mountain Time Zone (Mountain Standard Time - MST) / (Mountain Daylight Time - MDT during daylight saving time).
4) Pacific Time Zone (Pacific Standard Time - PST) / (Pacific Daylight Time - PDT during daylight saving time).
5) Alaska Time Zone (Alaska Standard Time - AKST) / (Alaska Daylight Time - AKDT during daylight saving time).
6) Hawaii-Aleutian Time Zone (Hawaii-Aleutian Standard Time - HAST) / (Hawaii-Aleutian Daylight Time - HADT during daylight saving time).

It should be noted that some regions of the United States may observe daylight saving time, which implies an adjustment in the acronyms of the time zones during that season. This may cause the number of time zones to temporarily change in those areas during daylight saving time.

instruction: What is established to examine legislative proposals presented by people outside the party? Apparently it's a committee. Can you give me some context?
output:
The process to examine legislative proposals presented by people outside the political party is established through a parliamentary committee or parliamentary commission. In many parliamentary systems, citizens or groups outside the party are allowed to submit legislative proposals, also known as citizen initiatives or legislative petitions.

These proposals can be on various topics, from reforms in existing laws to the creation of new laws. However, before a citizen proposal can become law, it generally must undergo a process of review and debate to ensure that it meets legal and constitutional requirements and standards.

The parliamentary committee or parliamentary commission responsible for examining these proposals plays a crucial role in this process. The committee is responsible for analyzing the proposal, evaluating its feasibility, debating its content and, ultimately, recommending whether it should be accepted, rejected or modified for subsequent consideration and vote by the legislative body.

The inclusion of citizens or external groups in the legislative process through citizen initiatives seeks to promote democratic participation and give voice to the interests and concerns of the population in general, allowing that laws are not exclusively formulated by legislators, but also by civil society.

instruction: In which country is the Tower of Pisa located?
output: The Tower of Pisa is a leaning tower located in Italy. This tower is located in the Piazza del Duomo in Pisa, in the city of the same name, a municipality in the Italian region of Tuscany and capital of the homonymous province of Italy. Its original height was 60 m, although it currently measures 56.67 m from the base on the highest side and 55.86 m from the base on its lowest side.  Its weight is estimated at 14,500 tons and its inclination is about 4°, extending 3.9 m from the vertical. It has eight levels: a base of blind arches with 15 columns, six levels adorned with open semicircular arches, and a bell tower at the top. The internal spiral staircase has 251 steps. It is considered, along with the cathedral of which it is a part, one of the jewels of Romanesque art.

instruction: Why can birds fly?
output:
Birds can fly due to a combination of physical adaptations and specific behaviors that allow them to generate lift and propulsion in the air. Here are some of the key reasons why birds can fly:

1. Adapted skeletal and muscular structure: Birds have hollow and light bones, which reduces their overall weight and facilitates flight. Additionally, their flight muscles, such as the pectoralis major muscle, are specially developed and connect to the wings to allow the movement necessary to flap them.

2. Wings designed for flight: Birds' wings are uniquely designed for flight. They have an aerodynamic shape that allows them to generate lift when moving through the air. The wing consists of several parts, such as feathers, that help control airflow and the direction of flight.

3. Feathers: Feathers are key structures for flight. Primary and secondary feathers on the wings generate lift and allow control and direction during flight. Additionally, feathers also help maintain body temperature and provide protection.

4. Fused bones: Birds have fused bones in certain areas, such as the pelvic girdle, which increases stability during flight.

5. High metabolism: Birds have a high metabolism that provides them with the energy necessary for flight. Flight requires considerable effort and a large amount of energy to maintain movement and lift.

6. Efficient respiratory system: The respiratory system of birds, which includes air sacs, allows a constant flow of air through the lungs, providing a continuous supply of oxygen necessary for the high energy demands of flight.

7. Flight Behavior: Birds have developed specialized flight behaviors that allow them to maneuver, take off, and land effectively. These behaviors include gliding, flapping, and diving.

8. Ability to learn and adapt: ​​Birds are able to learn and adapt to changing wind and environmental conditions, allowing them to fly efficiently and safely.

9. Efficient cardiovascular system: The cardiovascular system of birds 
It is also adapted to support the energy demand during flight. The heart of birds is relatively large and efficient at pumping oxygen-rich blood to muscles and other organs.

In summary, birds can fly thanks to a combination of anatomical, physiological and behavioral characteristics that allow them to generate lift and propulsion in the air. These unique adaptations have allowed them to conquer the sky and occupy a wide variety of ecological niches around the world.

instruction: What was the Cananea Strike?
output: The Cananea Strike was a labor strike at the Cananea copper mine, in the state of Sonora, Mexico, which was carried out against the company "Cananea Consolidated Copper Company" (CCCC). This company was owned by an American named William C. Greene, the strike was very similar to that of Río Blanco, Veracruz. It began on June 1, 1906 and was due to the exploitation and misery that the workers experienced, as well as the injustice and inequality between Mexican and American workers, because according to the strikers, "the development achieved in Mexico did not benefited the people or the workers in no way. The strike ended on June 5 of the same year after clashes between Mexican workers and American workers, which were initiated by the latter supported by more than 200 gunmen who illegally crossed the border into Mexico from Arizona. The situation resulted in the death of 23 people, mostly Mexican miners; The strike leaders were arrested by Mexican government forces following the voluntary withdrawal of the American invaders.

instruction: Given the answer: The embargo, what has a negative influence on the United States economy? Write a text that explains it:
output:
The Embargo and its Negative Influence on the United States Economy

The trade embargo, a restriction imposed by a country to limit or prohibit trade with another nation, can have a significant impact on the United States economy. Throughout history, the United States has used embargoes with different countries and for various reasons, but their implementation has had negative consequences on the national and global economy.

One of the most notable effects of the embargo is its impact on international trade. By limiting or prohibiting imports and exports with certain countries, market opportunities for American companies are reduced. This directly affects exporters and importers who depend on trade with sanctioned nations. Furthermore, lack of access to certain goods and services can cause shortages in the domestic market, which affects consumers and increases prices.

The embargo can also affect diplomatic and political relations with other countries. Depending on the context, nations affected by the embargo may retaliate with their own trade restrictions or political measures, leading to international tensions. These tensions can create uncertainty in financial markets and weaken investor confidence, which in turn can have a negative effect on economic growth.

Additionally, the embargo can create a negative perception of the United States in the international community. As news of trade restrictions spreads, some countries may view the embargoing country as an unreliable trading partner unwilling to abide by international trade rules. This may lead to a reduction in foreign direct investment and affect the global image of the United States as a country open to trade and international cooperation.

The embargo can also have social and humanitarian impacts. Embargoes can sometimes adversely affect the civilian population of sanctioned countries, making it difficult to access basic goods and services, including food and medicine. This can cause a humanitarian crisis and affect the most vulnerable people.

Other legal requirements come from malum prohibitum considerations or things that are a matter of custom or expectation, such as isolating businesses to a business district and residences to a residential district. A lawyer can request changes or exemptions in the law governing the land on which the building will be built, either arguing that a rule is inapplicable (the bridge design will not cause a collapse) or that the custom is no longer necessary (the acceptance of work spaces in homes has grown in the community).

Biden already has 290 votes in the Electoral College but there are still some states to be defined that could increase that number.

With Arizona, the Democratic candidate adds 11 additional votes in the Electoral College and climbs to 290, 20 more than required to win the presidency. 

As of Thursday night, Donald Trump was projected to win 217 votes.

In the Arizona election, Biden reached a narrow lead of 11,000 votes, equivalent to 0.3 percentage points, and is on track to be the first Democratic candidate to win there since Bill Clinton did so in 1996.

Four years ago, Trump emerged victorious in that state with a 3.5 percentage point lead over Hillary Clinton, whom he defeated in the race for the White House.

End of Maybe you're also interested

Biden's victory, however, has been questioned by the current president, who has denounced the existence of alleged electoral fraud although he has not provided evidence... The article continues.
output:
Usually, the name of the winner of the American presidential elections is known on the same night of election day, which on this occasion was November 3.

However, this year's elections have been more complex than usual as they were affected by the coronavirus pandemic, which prompted millions of citizens to vote by mail or in advance.

Trump denounced fraud but has not provided evidence to prove it.

It is estimated that some 100 million Americans had exercised their right in this way before the date of the election.

This unprecedented number had an impact on the process of counting results because in some states these votes were not allowed to be counted until the same day or even after election day had concluded.

That is what, in part, explains why the final results of all the states are not yet known.

The other element that has given greater complexity to these elections has been Trump's refusal to recognize the projections that grant victory to Biden, as well as numerous legal appeals filed by his campaign team to challenge the results.

instruction: How does the backpropagation algorithm work?
output:
Any function can be represented by a computational graph where each vertex represents an operation. For example, the function f(a, b, x) = sqrt(a*x + b) can be represented by the following graph:

A node v1 represents the value a, another node v2 represents the value x, and another node v3 represents the value b.
Then, a new node v4 represents a*x, another node v5 represents a*x + b, and a last node v6 represents sqrt(a*x+b).

In other words v1 := a, v2 := x, v3 := b. Then v4 := v1 * v2, v5 := v4 + v3, v6 := sqrt(v5). What we are doing is representing the function f as a composition of other simpler functions.

Then, when we need to compute the derivative of the function f with respect to a,b,x, we use the Leibnitz chain rule, which says that if df/dx = df/dg * dg/dx.

Then, we can compute the derivatives dv6/dv5, dv5/dv4, and dv5/dv3, and dv4/dv1, dv4/dv2, and in this way we can compute the derivative of f with respect to the three variables a,b,x at a particular point. To do this, we first make a forward pass, to compute f(a,b,x) at the given values, and then we make a backward pass according to the chain rule.

instruction: Why doesn't the Moon fall?
output:
The Moon does not fall toward Earth due to a balance between two fundamental forces, the force of gravity and the moon's orbital speed, a combination of its motion. Here are the key factors that prevent the Moon from hurtling toward Earth:

1. Orbital motion: The Moon is in constant motion around the Earth in an elliptical orbit. This motion is similar to how a free-falling object follows a curved path as it falls. However, due to the Moon's tangential speed and inertia, it continues to move horizontally instead of falling directly toward Earth.

2. Centrifugal force: As the Moon moves in its orbit around the Earth, it experiences a centrifugal force due to its motion in the opposite direction to gravity. This force partially balances the gravitational pull and helps keep the Moon in its orbit.

3. Gravitational balance: The Earth's gravity exerts an attractive force on the Moon, and this force tends to attract it towards the Earth. However, due to the Moon's inertia and its orbital motion, these gravitational and centrifugal forces are in balance, resulting in a stable orbit.

4. Adequate orbital speed: The Moon has an adequate orbital speed that allows it to maintain its distance from the Earth and not fall towards it. If the Moon were too slow, it would fall toward the Earth, and if it were too fast, it would escape orbit.

In summary, the balance between gravitational force and orbital speed results in a stable orbit for the moon around the Earth. In other words, the Moon does not fall towards the Earth due to a combination of its orbital motion, the centrifugal force generated by this motion, and the Earth's gravity. These factors work together to keep the Moon in a stable orbit around our planet.

instruction:
Please consider the text below and answer the following question: Could John Neal be considered a contributor to the fight for equality in the United States of America?

John Neal (August 25, 1793 – June 20, 1876) was an American writer, critic, editor, lecturer, and activist. Considered eccentric and influential, he gave speeches and published essays, novels, poems, and short stories between the 1810s and 1870s in the United States and Great Britain, in which he championed early American literary nationalism and regionalism. Neal promoted the development of American art, fought for women's rights, advocated for the end of slavery and racial prejudice, and helped establish the American gymnastics movement.

John Neal is the first American author to use natural diction and a pioneer of colloquialisms, and also the first to use the phrase "son-of-a-bitch" in a work of fiction. He achieved his greatest literary achievements between 1817 and 1835, during which time he was the first American published in British literary journals, the author of the first history of American literature, the first American art critic, a pioneer of children's literature, and a forerunner of the American Renaissance. As one of the first men to advocate for women's rights in the U.S. and the first American lecturer on the subject, for more than fifty years he supported women writers and organizers, asserted intellectual equality between men and women, fought against covert laws against women's economic rights, and demanded suffrage, equal pay, and better education for women. He was the first American to establish a public gymnasium in the US and championed athletics to regulate the violent tendencies he himself had struggled with throughout his life.
output: Yes, according to the text provided, John Neal was an advocate of women's rights and opposed slavery.

instruction: How can I mount two monitors for my computer?
output:
Setting up two monitors for your computer may seem complex, but I'll break it down into simple steps to help you. First of all, you will need two monitors, obviously, and a computer that has enough power and connections for both monitors. To be more specific, the computer must have two video ports (where the monitor cables connect). These ports can be HDMI, VGA, DVI or DisplayPort; the type doesn't matter as long as you have two of them. Secondly, you will need cables to connect the monitors to the computer. The type of cable depends on the type of port; For example, the HDMI port needs an HDMI cable. If the ports on your monitors and the ports on your computer are different, you may need an adapter.

Now, these are the steps to configure the two monitors:

1. Turn on your computer.
2. Connect the first monitor to the first video port on your computer using the appropriate cable. Do the same with the second monitor and the second video port. 
3. Right-click on the desktop and select "Display Settings" or "Screen Resolution", depending on your operating system. 
4. A new window will open and here you will see two boxes representing your monitors. You can drag these boxes to match the physical layout of your monitors. 
5. Make sure both monitors are set to "Extend Displays" mode in the "Multiple Displays" drop-down menu. This will allow the pointer to move between monitors. 
6. Click "Apply" and then "OK" to save the changes. 

And ready! Now you can use both monitors for different tasks and increase your productivity. If you have any problems, don't hesitate to ask.

instruction: Why is the Sun so big and there are no humans living there?
output:
The Sun is a star and is much larger than the Earth due to gravitational forces and thermonuclear processes in its core, the nature of its formation and function in the cosmos. Here are the main reasons:

1. Star formation: The Sun formed from a cloud of gas and dust in a region of our galaxy known as the Milky Way. These clouds collapse under the influence of gravity, causing an increase in temperature and pressure in the core. When these conditions reach certain thresholds, nuclear fusion begins in the core, converting hydrogen to helium and releasing enormous amounts of energy in the form of light and heat. This nuclear fusion is what keeps the Sun shining and generating energy.

2. Size and composition: The Sun has an approximate diameter of around 1.4 million kilometers, which is about 109 times the diameter of the Earth. Its volume is approximately 1.3 million times the volume of the Earth. This is due to the massive amount of material that condensed in the core during its formation, and the extremely high pressure and temperature in the core allow nuclear fusion to occur.

3. Temperature and gravity: The temperature at the core of the Sun is extremely high, reaching around 15 million degrees Celsius (27 million degrees Fahrenheit). This high temperature and the enormous mass of the Sun generate significant gravity, which maintains the balance between the expansion force of the energy released by fusion and the gravitational pull towards the center.

4. Inhospitable environment: The Sun is not a suitable place for human life due to its extreme conditions. The Sun's surface, called the photosphere, has temperatures of about 5,500 degrees Celsius (9,932 degrees Fahrenheit). In addition, the outer layers of the Sun, such as the corona, are much hotter and emit intense radiation such as X-rays and ultraviolet rays. These conditions would make life as we know it on Earth impossible.

5 Radiation: The Sun emits a massive amount of radiation, including ultraviolet light and X-rays, which would be lethal to any living organism without extremely advanced protection. 
 
In short, the Sun is so large because of its formation as a star and the nuclear fusion that occurs in its core. The extreme conditions and high temperatures on the Sun make it inhospitable to human life, and living there would be impossible due to the intense radiation and extreme temperatures.

instruction: What is reinforcement learning?
output: Reinforcement learning is a trial and error machine learning technique. To do this, the software needs to interact with an environment, real or simulated. instruction: How did Luther's teaching on life after death compare to that of other theologians? Considering the previous question, write a context that contains the answer. It can be from 1 to 20 sentences.
output: Luther's teaching on life after death differed significantly from that of other theologians of his time, especially in the context of the Protestant Reformation. While the Catholic Church held a belief in purgatory as a place of purification for souls before entering heaven, Luther rejected this idea and affirmed that salvation was a free gift from God granted by faith in Jesus Christ. Furthermore, Luther emphasized the importance of the Bible as the ultimate authority in matters of faith and practice, in contrast to the traditions and teachings of the church. These ideas influenced the formation of Protestantism and generated a significant transformation in the understanding of life after death in 16th century Europe.

instruction: Explain the Pythagorean theorem.
output:
The Pythagorean theorem is a very famous theorem in Euclidean geometry. It is defined within the framework of a right triangle, which is a triangle where one of the angles measures exactly 90 degrees.

First, let's see that the longest side of a right triangle (which is the side opposite the 90 degree angle) is called the hypotenuse. The other sides (adjacent to the 90 degree angle) are called legs. The Pythagorean theorem says that the square of the length of the hypotenuse is the sum of the squares of the lengths of the legs. Mathematically, if h is the length of the hypotenuse, and a and b are the lengths of the legs, then h^2 = a^2 + b^2.

This theorem allows us to find any side of the right triangle, knowing the other two. Additionally, it allows us to identify if a triangle is right-angled based on the lengths of its sides.

instruction: Why doesn't the Moon fall?
output:
The Moon does not fall towards Earth due to a balance between fundamental forces gravity and the moon's orbital speed, a combination of its motion. Here are the key factors that prevent the Moon from hurtling toward Earth:

1. Orbital motion: The Moon is in constant motion around the Earth in an elliptical orbit. This motion is similar to how a free-falling object follows a curved path as it falls. However, due to the Moon's tangential speed and inertia, it continues to move horizontally instead of falling directly toward Earth.

2. Centrifugal force: As the Moon moves in its orbit around the Earth, it experiences a centrifugal force due to its motion in the opposite direction to gravity. This force partially balances the gravitational pull and helps keep the Moon in its orbit.

3. Gravitational balance: The Earth's gravity exerts an attractive force on the Moon, and this force tends to attract it towards the Earth. However, due to the Moon's inertia and its orbital motion, these gravitational and centrifugal forces are in balance, resulting in a stable orbit.

4. Adequate orbital speed: The Moon has an adequate orbital speed that allows it to maintain its distance from the Earth and not fall towards it. If the Moon were too slow, it would fall toward the Earth, and if it were too fast, it would escape orbit.

In short, the Moon does not fall towards the Earth due to a combination of its orbital motion, the centrifugal force generated by this motion, and the Earth's gravity. These factors work together to keep the Moon in a stable orbit around our planet.

instruction: According to Muisca mythology, how is the world formed?
output:
According to Muisca mythology, the world is called Quyca, and is formed as follows:
Quyca: The world itself.
Guatquyca: The world above, where Sua (god of the Sun) and Chie (goddess of the Moon) live, as well as other deities.
Tynaquyca: The world below, where the deceased live. According to this belief, the dead, after crossing a dark ravine, must cross a river riding a raft made of spider webs, called Sospquazine, until they reach a place, in the bowels of the earth, full of illuminated crop fields. for a new Sun.

instruction: Summarise the article: Both boys and girls should be given the HPV vaccine to prevent rising cancer rates, experts say. The vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect them against the human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer. But the virus is actually thought to trigger 5 per cent of all cancers worldwide, including those affecting 2,000 men a year. Girls aged 12 and 13 are currently offered the HPV vaccine to help protect against cervical cancer, which is caused by the human papillomavirus. An expert committee working for the Department of Health is currently deciding whether boys aged 12 to 13 should also be offered the vaccine. Campaigners say it would save lives, prevent unnecessary suffering and save the NHS millions of pounds in treatment costs. The vaccines would be offered voluntarily to children at school and would cost the health service up to £22m a year. HPV is transmitted through sexual contact and causes cervical cancer in women, as well as cancers of the throat, anus and penis. Experts on the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation are expected to meet yesterday to make a final decision next month. Girls aged 12 and 13 have been offered the vaccine voluntarily since 2008 and around 80% have taken it. Peter Baker, campaign director of HPV Action.org, said it was "blatantly unfair" that women were protected against cancer and other diseases caused by HPV infection while men were not. "Men will continue to die from HPV-related diseases unless the government acts to extend the national vaccination programme to all teenage boys," he said. This would only cost around £20-22m a year and in the long run would save money spent by the NHS on treatment and reduce human suffering. If parents knew that both their sons and daughters could be protected from the virus that causes 5 per cent of all cancers then I am sure most would agree too." Earlier this month, MPs from the all-party parliamentary groups on cancer, dentistry, sex and reproduction...
output: Girls aged 12 and 13 are offered the injection to protect them against cervical cancer. The Department of Health meets to decide whether the vaccine should be extended to 12- and 13-year-olds. The human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the disease and is thought to trigger 5% of cancers worldwide, including those that affect 2,000 men a year. It is also linked to cancer of the throat, anus and penis.

instruction: Where is Capurgana Colombia and how to go there?
output:
The town of Capurganá belongs to the municipality of Acandí, department of Chocó. Capurganá, which means “land of chili peppers,” is located in the far north of Colombia, very close to the border with Panama. 
You can travel to Capurganá by plane from Medellín, Olaya Herrera Airport, directly on a charter flight. These direct flights last approximately one hour and change frequency depending on the season. In the low season they only operate two days a week, so make sure you buy your ticket in advance.

instruction:
To summarize: The three American scientists have been studying the circadian rhythm of the fruit fly for three decades.

The Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, Sweden, said it recognized them for their "discoveries of the molecular mechanisms that control the circadian rhythm," that is, our biological clock.

"Their discoveries explain how plants, animals and humans adapt their biological rhythm to synchronize with the revolutions of the Earth," the Assembly said in a statement.

The three scientists are pioneers in the study of our biological clock.

Their research allowed us "to take a look inside our biological clock and elucidate its internal workings," the institution explained. 

The biological clock is responsible for making us sleepy at night and influences our mood, alertness and even our risk of suffering cardiac arrest.

"What this can do is make us more aware of the importance of sleep hygiene and how important it is to make sure that we are going to bed at an appropriate time," said Juleen Zierath of the Assembly. 

The prize amounts to US$1.1 million and is the first of the Nobel Prizes to be announced each year. On Tuesday the name of the winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics will be revealed; on Wednesday, Chemistry; on Thursday, Literature; on Friday, Peace and on Monday the 9th, Economy.

The Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded last year to Japanese biologist Yoshinori Ohsumi for discovering the mechanisms behind cellular autophagy, the process of cell degradation and recycling.

Pioneers in their field

The three scientists are pioneers in the study of biological rhythm.

Rosbash and Hall began collaborating at Brandeis University in Boston more than 30 years ago to study the circadian rhythm of Drosophila, the fruit fly family. 

Both were the first to clone the first circadian rhythm gene of this fly in 1984.

The prize amounts to US$1.1 million...\nSummary in the same language as the doc:
output: American researchers Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash and Michael W. Young were awarded this Monday with the 2017 Nobel Prize in Medicine.

instruction: What are the main questions facing humanity?
output:
Throughout history, humanity has explored a variety of fundamental questions that have driven knowledge and the search for answers. Some of humanity's biggest questions include:

1. What is the origin of the universe?: The question of how the universe began has been a constant concern, giving rise to theories such as Biblical creationism, Big Bang and modern cosmology.

2. What is the purpose of life?: The search for purpose in life has led to philosophical, religious and scientific explorations in search of meaning.

3. Is there life beyond Earth?: The possibility of extraterrestrial life has been a recurring theme in science and popular culture, driving space exploration and the search for signs of life on other planets.

4. What is consciousness?: The nature of consciousness, that is, how thought and subjective experience arise, has long baffled scientists, philosophers and neuroscientists.

5. What is the nature of reality?: Questions about reality, existence, and perception have driven philosophy, physics, and metaphysics throughout history.

6. What is morality?: The search for universal ethical and moral principles has been a constant concern in philosophy and in the construction of legal and social systems.

7. How does the human mind work?: Psychology and neuroscience have sought to understand how the mind works, how thoughts are formed and how emotions develop.

8. Is it possible to travel in time?: The concepts of time travel have long intrigued humanity, generating debates in theoretical physics and science fiction.

9. What is beauty and art?: The appreciation of art and beauty has led to questions about subjectivity, creativity and human expression.

10. How to achieve peace and harmony?: The search for world peace and peaceful coexistence between nations and cultures has been a constant objective.

11. Where do we come from?: The question about the origin of life and humanity has led to research into biological evolution, cosmology and the formation of the universe.


12. What is good and evil?: Questions about ethics, morality, and the nature of good and evil have been addressed since creation.
These are just some of the major questions that have intrigued humanity throughout the centuries. The answers to these questions are often constantly evolving as we advance science, philosophy, and understanding of the world around us.

instruction: Who decides who will govern the city? Considering the previous question, write a context that contains the answer. It can be from 1 to 20 sentences. The context:
output: The city is governed in accordance with the Charter of Self-Government of the City of Detroit. The city government is led by a mayor and a nine-member city council and a clerk elected on a generally nonpartisan ballot. Since voters approved the city charter in 1974, Detroit has had a "strong mayor" system, and it is the mayor who approves departmental appointments. The council approves budgets but the mayor is not obligated to fulfill any assignments. City ordinances and substantially large contracts must be approved by the council. The Detroit City Code is the codification of Detroit's local ordinances.

instruction:
Content: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered on October 2, 2018.

I walked down a tree-lined street in a quiet part of Istanbul, Turkey, and approached a cream-colored mansion, adorned with CCTV cameras.

A year ago, an exiled Saudi journalist made the same journey: Jamal Khashoggi was recorded by CCTV cameras. They would be the last images ever captured of him.

He entered the Saudi consulate in the Turkish city and was killed by a death squad.

Jamal Khashoggi entered the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October 2, 2018, and never came out.

But the consulate was bugged by the Turkish intelligence service, so everything was recorded: the planning to kill him and the execution.

Only a few people have heard those tapes. Two of them spoke exclusively to the BBC's Panorama programme.

British baroness Helena Kennedy, a lawyer and human rights expert, listened to the agony of Jamal Khashoggi.

"The horror of hearing someone's voice, hearing the fear in their voice, and [knowing] that you're listening to something [that happened] live sends shivers down your spine."

Baroness Helena Kennedy listened to recordings that recorded the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

Kennedy took detailed notes of conversations she heard between members of the Saudi death squad.

"You can hear them laughing. It's a chilling affair. They're there, waiting, knowing that this man is going to come and he's going to be killed and dismembered."

Kennedy was invited to join a team led by Agnès Callamard, the UN special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions.

Callamard told me of her determination to use her own mandate to investigate the Khashoggi murder when the UN was reluctant to launch an international criminal investigation.

Agnès Callamard is a human rights expert and the current special rapporteur.

The above text can be summarised as follows:
output: Chilling details are revealed of the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of a death squad at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey.

instruction: What characterizes the sign of Cancer?
output:
Cancer, the fourth cardinal sign of the Zodiac, and the first of the Water element, represents the feminine, the fecund, and is governed by the emotions of the Moon. It is the sign of home, of roots, of the mother.
Its natives have great emotional sensitivity and deep faith. Guided by their powerful intuition, they know when to gamble and when to retreat in time in moments of risk. Its symbol is the crab and its movement has been interpreted as a source of permanent rebirth.
The sensitive imagination and the predominance of the emotional world are the most characteristic features of the sign, but, depending on how they are channeled, they can be a positive force or a point of weakness and vulnerability.
Loyal, emotional, constant, protective, traditionalist, sensual, intuitive, and sweet-toothed, this Water sign is associated with the need for security. In the crab that identifies it, that hard shell represents an introverted nature with an armor that is difficult to penetrate since they present a need for self-protection.
It is the sign that needs the most security of all and will always be waiting for a hug or demonstration of affection, which they do not hesitate to express.
Reflective and spiritual, those born with the Sun in Cancer have a prodigious imagination that they nourish in their moments of solitude. They love opening drawers with old photos and reminiscing about the nostalgia of the past. Generous and family-oriented, they tend to adapt to everything and everyone, although the excitement and nervousness that the Moon gives them makes them quite cyclothymic beings.
Arguing with a Cancer makes the debate somewhat predictable, they may explode with nerves if they feel hurt or questioned and after a while they will ask for forgiveness or try to remedy the situation because they cannot tolerate the idea of ​​seeing others and themselves in a bad light.
Emotional and susceptible, the crab cannot conceive of living without the company of another. Affection is your emotional nourishment and it is difficult for you to feel fulfilled until you find the ideal partner. They love the tranquility of home above all things and that is why they build their future without haste.
Slow and steady work is his thing as he doesn't trust quick and easy results. You can develop your intelligence to unsuspected limits. Noble by nature, their deep spiritual sense is combined with a prophetic intuition that guides them.

instruction: Were women considered less frequently? Write a context that contains the answer, considering an analysis focused on universal history. It can be from 1 to 20 sentences.
output:
Historically, in many societies and periods, women have been considered less often than men, facing discrimination and restrictions in various aspects of life. In most ancient civilizations, women had gender-assigned roles as caregivers of the home and children, which often limited their participation in the public and political sphere.

In ancient Greece, for example, women were excluded from citizenship and denied the right to education and to participate in political life. In ancient Rome, although some women from noble families had some influence, most were relegated to domestic and child-rearing roles.

During the Middle Ages, the Catholic Church reinforced the idea of ​​women's inferiority and their submission to men. Women were considered more prone to sin and were consequently denied access to certain religious and political positions.

The Renaissance and Enlightenment brought advances in thought, but women were still seen as intellectually inferior and their place was still primarily in the home.

It was in the 19th century that feminist movements began to emerge around the world, fighting for equal civil, political and economic rights for women. However, they still faced strong resistance and it was not until the 20th century that significant progress was made in terms of rights and recognition.

Despite these advances, the fight for gender equality continues in many places around the world today, highlighting that universal history has been marked by the unequal consideration of women compared to men.

instruction: Write an article about Margaret Thatcher, maximum 5,000 characters.
output:
Title: Margaret Thatcher: The Iron Lady and her Impact on British Politics

Introduction:

Margaret Thatcher, also known as the Iron Lady, was a prominent British political figure who left an indelible mark on the history of her country. As Prime Minister of the United Kingdom during a period of great transformation, Thatcher implemented bold and controversial policies that reshaped the economy, society and the role of government. In this article, we will explore the life and legacy of Margaret Thatcher, her political approach and her impact on British politics.

The life and political rise of Margaret Thatcher:

Margaret Hilda Roberts was born on 13 October 1925 in Grantham, Lincolnshire. From a young age, she showed great ambition and dedication to her studies, excelling academically at the University of Oxford. After graduating, she worked as a chemical scientist before entering politics.

Thatcher began her political career as a member of the Conservative Party and was elected to Parliament in 1959. Her rise was rapid, and in 1975 she became the first female leader of the Conservative Party. In 1979, she became the first female prime minister of the United Kingdom.

Thatcher's economic policies:

Thatcher became known for her neoliberal approach and her commitment to free market economics. Her economic policies, known as "Thatcherism", were based on the reduction of state intervention, the privatization of state companies, the reduction of taxes and the promotion of free competition.

During her tenure, Thatcher implemented sweeping reforms, including deregulating financial markets, diminishing the power of unions, and reducing inflation. These policies transformed the British economy and paved the way for sustained economic growth, but they also led to social inequalities and a widening gap between rich and poor.

Social policies and legacy:

Thatcher also left a lasting impact on British society. She advocated for greater individual responsibility and less dependence on the state, promoting conservative and traditional values. Her policies included cuts in public spending in areas such as education and health, which sparked criticism and protests.

Her forceful handling of labor disputes, especially during the miners' strike in the 1980s, made her a controversial and divisive figure. Thatcher took a strong stance in defense of national interests, and her authoritarian leadership won her both admirers and detractors.

Thatcher also played an important role in international politics, notable for her close relationship with U.S. President Ronald Reagan and her uncompromising stance toward the Soviet Union during the Cold War.

instruction: Martin Luther King was a great speaker, tell me a little about his life, his achievements, difficulties, Christian life, how he died and his legacy. Maximum 5000 characters.
output:
Martin Luther King Jr. was a prominent leader in the fight for civil rights and an influential speaker known for his advocacy of racial equality and nonviolence. Born on January 15, 1929 in Atlanta, Georgia, into a family of religious leaders, King was raised in an environment committed to the Christian faith and social justice values.

Throughout his life, King faced hardships and challenges as he fought for equal rights for African Americans. He graduated with honors in sociology and theology, earning his doctorate in 1955. In 1954, he became the pastor of Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Alabama, where he began to actively lead the civil rights movement. .

One of King's most notable achievements was his role in the Montgomery bus boycott of 1955-1956, which resulted in the desegregation of buses in that city. His focus on nonviolent resistance inspired many and gave him national recognition as a leader.

In 1963, King gave his famous "I Have a Dream" speech during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. In that speech, King articulated his vision of a society where people were judged by their character and not their race. This speech is a milestone in the fight for civil rights and is remembered as one of the most influential speeches in history.

However, King also faced opposition and violence from segregationist and racist groups. He was arrested several times and received death threats. Despite these adversities, King remained steadfast in his commitment to nonviolence and equality.

Tragically, on April 4, 1968, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee, by a gunman. His death shocked the nation and caused riots in various cities. Despite his untimely assassination, King's legacy continued to grow.

The legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. is immense. His work and sacrifice helped spur the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which eliminated many forms of racial discrimination and promoted equality. His focus on nonviolence and social justice influenced civil rights movements around the world. His birthday became a national holiday in the United States, and his influence is felt in the ongoing fight for equality, justice, and human rights.

instruction:
Please summarize the following article: (CNN) -- Nearly a million strollers have been recalled by their manufacturer after reports of at least 12 infants or toddlers having their fingers amputated after they were caught in the hinges. British company Maclaren said the recall concerns Chinese-made models on sale in the United States that open with an "umbrella" mechanism. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission said customers should stop using the strollers immediately. Maclaren said it was issuing a free repair kit to make the hinges safe. 

The CPSC said the warning concerned models dating back to 1999 sold at stores including Target and Babies R Us. The mechanism "poses a risk of fingertip amputation and laceration to the child when the consumer is unfolding it," the CPSC said in a statement issued jointly with Maclaren. Maclaren said its Volo, Triumph, Quest Sport, Quest Mod, Techno XT, Techno XLR, Twin Triumph, Twin Techno and Easy Traveller models, which sell for between $100 and $400, were affected. The manufacturer said its strollers met required safety standards but the recall was being enforced voluntarily to “alert the operator when opening or closing the stroller to the potential risk of injury.”

In a separate statement, Maclaren’s European arm said no recall was being issued in the European Union, where fewer injuries had been reported, despite higher sales. “We want to reassure our customers that they should continue to use their existing Maclaren buggies as they are safe when opened and closed correctly,” it said. "Our advice is that consumers should use the same level of caution and care as when opening or closing a car door or any other moving part that can be found in many other baby and toddler products. "There are a smaller number of similar incidents reported among the considerably larger number of Maclaren buggies sold in Europe. If a buggy is folded or unfolded in accordance with our operating instructions, the risk of injury is non-existent."

U.S. consumers can contact Maclaren at 877-688-2326 or visit www.maclaren.us/recal.com
output: Maclaren admits that some of its strollers put young children at risk of finger amputations and is withdrawing them from the market. The recall affects nearly one million strollers sold in the United States. The manufacturer has also made a kit available to buyers to make the hinges safe.

instruction: Who has been the president who has been reelected the most times in Mexico?
output: Antonio López de Santana was president of Mexico eleven times, however in actual time he did not even serve a six-year term.
